commentBody:
I think I'll sit down for the reactions to this one.

Nice Thursday, Dan!

What's the trick that I'm missing here? I've filled in the grid, and all the squares are correct,  but I can't get the "you're done" screen. Do I need to make a rebus with each of the missing letters?
Umm, ok.

Bold prediction:

People are going to hate this one. 

It is a real challenge. Nice to finish.
Nope. Just nope
Nah

Whether it’s the clueing, the fill, the theme, or some combination of all of the above, this fell off the tricky/rewarding tightrope into the pit of frustration. Gap between developer ambition and user experience on display.

I didn't understand the rules. I tried to put in rebuses, since it was Th. and it was obvious some words needed extra letters. I can solve puzzles if I know the rules, but I don't like changing / ad hoc rules.  Forgive my crankiness.

The tactical mistake I made on this one was spending too much time floundering before searching for the revealer clue, a piece of good advice I sometimes get too headstrong to remember.  While in this case the revealer only partially unlocked the mystery, it was enough to look to the edges for the missing letters.

I’m assuming many others also figured out the missing letters from the clues themselves without “solving” the hidden synonyms on the edges.
This was just not for me. No zest or sparkle, just frustration and indifference. I’m guessing this puzzle will get mixed reviews.

I found this especially hard for a Thursday. I think it probably would have been easier on paper, where you can write in the margins. Because the missing letters were invisible to me, I kept forgetting where they were (since the answers in the grid were all still valid words) and couldn't see what they were spelling.

That was different.

I'll stop at that.
I can foresee some strong + mixed opinions on this one but I really enjoyed it. Challenging (but not too challenging) and some great fill and cluing.

Very fun for me. The only issue I had was that I suspected the protruding letters were also related to the theme, but I don't have the visualization powers necessary to see it in my head. Even when I completed it, I had to screenshot it in the half second it was visible on my phone screen. Luckily, I didn't need that for any troublesome clues.
I enjoyed the puzzle, but ♪ I ain't askin' for much ♪♪ …

I liked this one very much. I figured out generally what was happening fairly early on, and got the gold star, but I didn’t get exactly what was happening off the grid until I glanced at Deb’s column. I didn’t need to see her depiction of the secret words, but I had a big “Aha!” moment in the second paragraph of “ Today’s Theme.”

And I appreciated the little dig at my local paper, the Washington Post, which I recently ditched after 30+ years when it went all billionaire-class on us. 

Thanks for a cool Thursday puzzle, Mr. Caprera!

There are going to be lots of people who have never seen this kind of puzzle before, but it makes a whole lot more sense to me than the crossout puzzle we just had.

Just my opinion.  I think the yays and nays will line up with a high correlation to experience.
Regarding 46A, would it be safe to say that the commentator pulled a 31D on William Shatner?

I never don't finish a puzzle. 
This one left me behind. No fun intended.

Cute fun theme, once I figured out what was, ahem, behind it.
Nice that all the behinds were arranged the same way on all four sides. (Hmm, that does sound a little sleazy…)
And that the butted-out words were real words!

Now, to try to get into the one-size-smaller jeans tomorrow…
Finished it correctly and I have no clue what the theme was other than missing letters. I’d rather have a REBUS puzzle than whatever that was, and I hate REBUS puzzles generally.

Many of the clues were outright dishonest.

Mayo to mayo?  Should’ve been Mayo to Mayo. Months are still capitalized in Spanish. Who needs grammar when a new constructor wants to be clever?

Abbreviated answers are also supposed to be indicated via abbreviations in clues. Single elims? Zero indication in the clue that an abbreviated colloquialism will be the answer.

Isms (which isn’t even a word) for credos? Come on. Ideology and creed aren’t even close to synonyms, even if “isms” is treated as a real word.

And if the Mayo nonsense weren’t enough, we got to end with MENSA, yet another abbreviation/acronym answer that was never indicated in the clue. 

I could also TAKE A DIG AT that awful Saturday answer that has no business in a Thursday puzzle.

The whole thing was a failed attempt at being clever. Just awful from beginning to end.
As el said, hard to get a handle on missing letters you can’t see.  Also, too much trivia for me, I prefer solving good riddles.

I think had I played the print version it would have made more sense, at least I’d be able to write the letters outside the grid. Much harder to keep track on the digital version, especially so when the constructor acknowledges the theme isn’t intuitive in the first place!

I’ve found this week much easier than usual, so while this was more of a grind than I was ready for, I do appreciate my first real challenge of the week. Thank you!
What a fun challenge!

Figured out the twist right away, got most of the puzzle in 10 min, and then spent 30 min on the SE corner trying various words with AbOve and ALOFT before finally giving up and doing some lookups.  I think I might have gotten DECOR if I stared at it for another 30 min.  The clues are still seem a bit clangy to me, to be honest.

Will have to remember arch = OGEE and mustang = TTOP from now on, the same way pasta = PENNE and hockey player = ORR.
I guess the eight-year-olds will enjoy this adventure in puerility. There was a scourge of juvenile bumfests a while back and I was hoping they were a thing of the past. But it was not to be.
So needed this fun puzzle and your witty remarks.
Got it. Hated it.

Nothing about this puzzle 
bum-med me, nor made me SAD, nor made me MOPE. 
It was glorious!

I noticed off the bat that the "T" was missing for (T)AILS, and the rest was delightful history, figuring out which other entries would have letters outside the grid. 

Thank you for a terrific Thursday, Mr. Caprera, with a grateful shout-out as well to the graphics team for the ICING on the cake.

Altogether, a work of art!
Actually, I did not find this difficult. I had to doublecheck because I had HALF TUNE for HALF TONE and TOTODO for TOTORO but I liked the puzzle itself.

Brilliant, brilliant, brilliant! I love those puzzles where I have no idea what I am doing, walk through the entire grid desperately hoping for something to stick, and the closest that I could come was BRAS for Generals and such -- not exactly a confidence builder. But bit by bit, square by square, the crossword yielded its secrets.

Now, the only question is, what's Dan going to do for an encore?
Brilliant theme, concept and execution, thank you!

I hate these puzzles.  I don't think it's neat or cool or clever to not follow the rules of crosswords.  I think it's lazy.  Usually I just click "reveal puzzle" the instant I realize that they haven't followed the rules of crosswords.

I figured out words were extending outside the grid, but I didn't make the connection that the letters formed synonyms for butt.

Clever puzzle, but it was a very slow solve.

As the kids would say, this puzzle is buns. I genuinely hate puzzles that make you guess what the rules are. This leaves an infinite range of possibilities. If that’s what the puzzler wanted, maybe they should have been a poet.  But if they poem like they puzzle, maybe it’s good they’re puzzling. So thanks, I guess.

I predict a lot of complaints, so let me add some praise: this was crunchy in a good Thursday way. It was a bit slow because I was having trouble keeping the extra letters in my head -- I got the revealer* and figured the letters would be outside the grid, and figured they'd make words relating to butts, but I hadn't pinged that they were symmetrical, and with a different word on each side ... slow. 

(*actually the HALFTON/NOONE clued me in first-- HALFTON via crosses, and I know the music one was missing an E ... couldn't be a standard rebus because the E didn't fit in, which meant outside letters or nonstandard rebus. But then BUTTOUT popped into my head, plus I realized the three letter "Field" could be ARE(A), and the E and A could be part of "rear" ... that side ended up being "seat", but potayto potahto.)

But(t) I enjoyed it :)
Hated it. Far too much obscure fill. Theme that was difficult to follow in the app. This one never should it made it past the editors.
for everyone complaining - what do you expect from a thursday? its supposed to be tricky and “break the rules” of the usual crossword

I solved rebus style and then had to go back and delete. Definitely weird to not be able to enter full answers. Enjoyed the puzzle but wonder if it's worth it to do the outside the grid thing with the current limitations of the app

I figured out the general idea quickly thanks to the revealer and clue 13A… but then way overthought everything after that. Went down the wrong path of thinking that all theme words were also related to the revealer (à la TAILS) and kept doubting everything that didn’t fit my preconceived notion. Definitely grateful for the Wordplay column help, this was beyond my ability to solve alone! 

That said, count me among the fans of Dan’s creation! I have only become a daily crossword solver in the past year or so and find these out-of-the-box puzzles fun and stimulating. I’ve seen a huge difference in how far I can get in the later days of the week and aspire to reach the levels of the experts on here who can solve Thursdays and Saturdays easily! I’m content (for now) with the fact that I 1) figured out the basic idea and 2) got pretty far… I loved the challenge!

UTA BAUM Dan Caprera!

Muy BUENO

Distant strains faintly heard a half tone low

"I see the bad moon rising
I see trouble's on the way..."

Cute but problematic as there is no way to mark the missing letters in the app. So it was hard to remember which letters had been butted out. I figured it out, and finished the puzzle, but it didn't work well without paper.
I cracked it!
What a tedious, tiresome puzzle. I think that if I didn't have a nice streak going I would just pass on these oh-so-cutesy entries.
I done did this.puu

I like the Thursday gimmicks; they're fun, whether refuses or other shenanigans. However, I solve in the app, and this is one that would have worked better with pencil and paper. 

I got the trick when I got the revealer BUTT OUT, and I realized something tuchas-related would be outside of the grid. And that explained some of the entries that seemed to be missing a letter, but didn't really seem like a rebus would work in both directions. But there's really not a way (that I know of) to add letters beyond the confines of the grid in this app. So maybe next time I run across this kind of tomfoolery, I'll print the puzzle, then I may scribble as I please. 

Fun trick and challenging puzzle! Overall, I enjoyed it. Thank you, Dan Caprera and Will Shortz. 

I imagine there will be complaints... this kind of buffoonery doesn't sit well with the more rigid solvers.

I read the column after solving the puzzle and not understanding the theme/trick. I knew it had to do with some edge letters being omitted but the animation with the red letters went by too fast, and all I could see was the word "TRUMP" flashing in the upper part of the puzzle, which gave me the ick. Still, this puzzle is a good reminder that you can't spell "Trump" without "rump."

Most annoying puzzle I’ve faced yet. Too clever by half. And ultimately a most rewarding solve.

With Tuesday’s mockery of a “themed” puzzle still fresh in my mind I was getting preemptively peeved by a seeming lack of meaning BEHIND the omitted letters in this one but finally saw it once the south border filled out. Always appreciate a completion animation as well. Great stuff Dan, brilliant construction!
I finished it and didn't like it.

I don't really get the hate for this one. I guess if you haven't done one like this it could be frustrating, but once I realized there were letters missing around the edges I didn't find the fill overly difficult or obscure.

Had to print out the puzzle halfway through when I realized that some of the answers extended beyond the grid - something that the app or online versions could not provide without giving it away.

I don't think it's the fault of the constructor - I actually enjoyed solving it (except for a few clues such as 41 and 44 Across which were weak), but joy of solving has been diluted by limitation of the app/online versions.

Not one for me.
I do crosswords for the words, not to indulge the author’s fantasies

A bit on the fence about this one but leaning toward positive. I got the general gist pretty quickly, and the revealer solidified things. My negative was that the cluing was a little difficult for a theme where you have some (theoretically) unchecked squares out of the grid. On the other hand, once you do get the full theme you can start to guess the words around the edges, which does check even the letters outside the grid. And I needed every bit of that to solve the puzzle. So my final thought is—challenging, ultimately fair, and a theme that is actual useful to solve the puzzle—so, thumbs up.

Count me among the ones who enjoyed this puzzle. Caught on to the trick fairly early, and even noticed the missing letters spelled out posterior synonyms. I don't normally figure out that layer of the theme without reading the Wordplay column. I found the trivia gettable from the crossings, and I even came in 12 minutes under my Thursday average! I guess my mind is floating down the same gutter as Dan's.
I appreciate the clever construction, but those of us solving in the app don’t have anywhere to jot extraneous letters “outside the box” to keep track of where they are exiting and entering.
I didn’t like anything about this one. I’m always grateful for anyone who puts together a puzzle for our enjoyment, but I almost broke a 140+ day streak just to be done with it.
A real PITA--as it were.

Done in at the end by misspelling PELOTONS (PELeTONS) and not knowing my biology (OLDER instead of ORDER). 

LIVETH and its clue gave me a chuckle and any puzzle with I'm Just KEN is okay by me.

Please don't stop giving us puzzles like this.

I struggled a bit but still finished within an hour (good for a Thursday for me). I didn’t know the “butting out” letters spelled words until I read the write up, so that definitely helped order some of the chaos I felt while trying to solve. It’s one of those puzzles that I didn’t necessarily enjoy during, but satisfied afterward!
Fittingly for a rear-themed puzzle, this one was definitely a real pain in the a...rse :^) but still a satisfying one!

Well, i really enjoyed it, Dan. Thanks! I cottoned on pretty quickly to the letters getting BUTTed OUT, even though, like many, i didn't know they spelled out butt synonyms until reading Deb's column. I saw red letters moving away in the animation, but didn't grok that they formed words.

I thought the answer to 66A, "This might come in a saucer," was truly delightful. For quite a while i thought it would be cream.
I'm going to add my hat int the ring to say hat I thought the them was relatively easy, but the cluing was quit har. The time say 37 minute, but it really too me 3 hour

Great puzzle, and dont't listen to naysayers. Kindly suggest folks who don't like to think outside the box (ha) stick to the 5 days of the week that play it straight, and let the rest of us get some more synapses firing on Thursday and Sunday. No other puzzle platform (I'm aware of) has such a breadth of variety and stimulation, and puzzles like this contribute to that! BRAVO!

I found this to be pretty easy except for the SW corner. Since the letters outside the grid were only in my head, I didn’t notice their symmetrical locations nor the fact that they spelled butt synonyms. It took me a long time to see 62A THOU and 56D IOTA, and 68A MIA Goth is not a name I know.

Thanks for an appropriately challenging Thursday, Mr. Caprera!

I came to the column for help when this wasn't working as a rebus puzzle, even when I tried cutting it some slack.  

Inside jokes that seem clever and fun to a joker who is the only one who knows how it works are often not very funny, and in this case, this outside joke wound up seeming self-congratulatory and smug. 

Butt jokes can trigger hysterical laughter from children, but most of us here are grownups, and for me, this wasn't enough to make up for the annoyance of trying to guess what the kid was up to.  

Thanks for trying, Mr. Caprera. A lot of the clues were really good, but they were worthy of a better crossword.

Loved the theme and loved the puzzle solving. Folks that dislike anything other than a straightforward solve should probably avoid Thursdays. For those of us that love the creative twist, this is a fun one! Best day of the week.
a classic Thursday slog. Should've been left in the editor's room.
Puzzles like this one make me look forward to AI taking over. Or maybe it already has.
1A sums up my sentiments: NOPE

Cool puzzle, unfortunately ruined a bit for me by the online interface - I imagine on paper would be more fun as you could just write the extra letters outside the grid.

I imagine it accepted either the rebus or just the second letter? I was putting in the second letter and it made it harder to find and keep track of where the "extra" letters were, especially since the interface doesn't let you replace things that have already been autochecked as "correct".
This was no fun in the app.  The info button could have been used to point out that this puzzle was best done on paper.

Unseen letters outside the grid?!  Yep, they can do that.  

Fifty some years of solving the NYT crossword puzzles lets me take this type of theme twist in stride, but I empathize with those seeing it for the first time.

Anything goes, especially on Thursdays.

OGEE! it's a Thursday. Woohoo, indeed, Mr. Ocho Caprera!

Do do do, do do do
Do, do do . . 

SAD,  I"m crying,
Looky hard but still I NOTSEE
LAID and ENTRIES
LIDS off these words, SUPPLE and free

Dan's borders denied, 
NOONE can ignore 
But when I see EATS BUBBLING
I can take it all

SATURN wine so fine, 
OILS my mind
And the PLUM tart seems to fill my R E A R 
Let's ORDER PLAINTOAST with ICING and beer
And my T U S H seems to disappear!
Disappear, disappear, disappear, disappear, disappear, disappear, disappe...
Glad that’s over. Not fun.
This puzzle was a pain in the... Well, you know.

Hmm, there seems to be a sharp division of opinion on this puzzle. Put me in the thumbs up camp — I found it challenging but fun and not at all tedious. The animation with the missing letters was a nice surprise at the end!

I was not happy with ITEM for “thing on a docket” because, asa retired lawyer, I think of dockets as being filled with cases; agendas (agendae?) are filled with items.

In general, once I realized the import of the revealer, the missing letters outside the grid became obvious.  But on 55D, I didn’t even realize until I saw the animation that it was one of the theme entries, because, depending on what restaurants you go to, a waiter might very well pull out a CHAI.

Not sure which word clued me in to the theme, butt I got it shortly after filling in the revealer. Loved seeing TOTORO! “Tonari no Totoro” (My Neighbor Totoro) the movie came out shortly before I lived in Japan, so it was still big when I was there. There is now a musical play, in London’s West End, which I highly recommend for anyone who can go.
Got a kick out of Deb’s write up and all the butt jokes. Thx!

I do often enjoy a Thursday puzzle. It took about a year of solving before I was able to get some Thursday themes on my own. It always feels great to figure out the trick. Then again, given my rather simple mind I'm resigned to failing this time of the week, too. A tricky theme combined with unfamiliar fill will always get me. Today was one of those days.

The fill was just impossibly hard for me - all those names and trivia were just personally ungettable. Combined with a theme I just could not understand, it made for the most frustrating solving experience since the art heist Sunday abomination many months ago. 

I had to reveal 20 answers, if not more, which helped me to get some others on my own. However, I just did not get the theme, at all. I understood that probably some letters were out of bounds (because they butted out?), but which and why those? In the end I just gave up and turned to the column, and then revealed the puzzle.

I'm notoriously bad at thinking outside the box in some contexts, and I'm probably not very smart, either. That's on me, obviously. Still, it feels bad to be reminded of it by a puzzle 🤣

Also, I really don't like the clue for (s)ENTRIES - I only understood it with the column's help. Sentries don't say "halting" - if anything, they say "halt!" I know there was a question mark in the clue, but c'mon... "Halters?" would have been better, IMO.

I thought this was *brilliant* but I have to complain that I finished the puzzle with the extra-grid letters as rebuses, and when I didn’t get the music I spent a long time reviewing everything before I realized I just had to remove the extra letters. Why couldn’t the rebus entries be acceptable? 

To reiterate, though: GENIUS! I love Thursdays!!!

To present such a puzzle without an appropriate disclaimer, knowing in advance that the prospect of solution depends in no small part on printing it out versus solving online, seems to me not only a sort of betrayal to entusiasts but an esthetic bungle as well.
Broke my 80-something streak and might well have ruined my morning.

I understood the revealer early on, figured some letters would be missing/butt out, but had a hard time guessing the spacing of the outside word's letters. That meant not knowing when to expect a butt-out. The clues were somewhat unusual, not bad, but odd and a bit hard for a Thursday.

The theme was really good actually. I wish they would accept the extra letters in the rebus as well, nonetheless still a really well done theme idea.

I got stuck on all the names though, some fairly obscure (for me) ones. The names being close to each other didn't help either.

Also the "musical pitch interval" clue - I don't think I've ever seen that particular term used for it. I've always heard people refer to it as a Semitone. Being part of the theme didn't make this easier either.

Nice one, Deb: “You will see butts emerge from your puzzle, which, for my money, is worth the price of a subscription alone. It’s not as if you’re going to get this kind of highbrow entertainment from The Washington Post.”

I absolutely loved the puzzle!  Tricky, yes, but so satisfying to finally solve and figure out the four words outside the puzzle.  Once I figured out the trick, some of those four words helped me figure out areas where I was stuck.

NOPE. Just no fun. 

No, not "just" actually ... much more than that. The opposite of fun. 
Un-fun. In an unpleasant way.

Silly (and next to impossible to follow on the Android app) theme trick aside... How does this one annoy me? Let me list some ways:

TORTORO? PABLO? ALAIN? Japanese liqueur? 
There's trivia. And then there's Trivia. With a capital T.  

TAUTEN? So obscure a word that I, a word loving life-long reader (by which I mean I've been reading for 65 years or so) had to check the dictionary to see if it existed. (According to Google's ngram viewer, it had a peak popularity in 1929 at a bit less than 1 in a trillion printed words, or 0.0000000986%. Since 1950, it hasn't been above 0.5 per trillion).

The perfectly cromulent pronoun THOU, familiar from both the King James Bible and Shakespeare, clued as an amount of money with no hint towards it being either slang or an abbreviation. 

SEEP not= permeate (to permeate is to suffuse; be ubiquitous; fill. To SEEP is to slowly leak)

MOPE not= "Be" anything - not even down in the dumps. (MOPE is something one does, or a person who mopes, not a state one can be in)

Also, as a non-American, ESPNU, CNN (as clued), and MTA might as well be Japanese hooch.

I do not believe 34A was not deliberate, but I needed Deb's coy direction of the importance of a tilde in some Spanish words. 

Sometimes I solve the puzzle but don't get the Wordplay photo and caption. I admit that I am at this moment stymied, but my brain is a little worn out after 

...COMPLETING THE SOLVE! YAY ME!
Realised what was happening halfway through the puzzle. Hated it. Clicked reveal puzzle & moving on with my day.

Yeah, sure. It's a puzzle and I figured it out, but after years of entering rebus answers such as 30A's H A L F T O N/E one way, and not getting the music with H A L F T O NE another way I finally got wise and corrected it one last time and got the happy tune and graphics. However, is this the face of the puzzle department in this new villain era where its screw em, we'll do it our way and not let em in on the secret?

By the bye, thanks to Dan Caprera for a great puzzle!

Cute! When I couldn't get a number of obvious answers to fit, my first thought was that the theme was going to revolve around not having either or both of the  2 letters as suggested by clue 1 acc, but that didn't work out. I knew something was up, (level 1 complication). I didn't actually make the 2nd level twist connection with the central clue, which in my head made some weird sense with what I thought. 
Some localisms I intuited (CNN, ESPNU) others as usual had to search (not my native experience therefore not cheating), and Spanish is not my forte, not that I mind. (Or do I mean fortaleza?) Finding the name of the estuary was left to the cross-clues, no help from Mr Google there.
When I read about the animation I went back for a look as I had closed it too fast to see it. I did expect to see actual animated pink cartoon theme thingies, though, not just the words. Still a bonus though, and still pretty chuffed to figure it out with the first level twist and have a chuckle at the reveal.
Sure made me think a lot more than any puzzle in recent memory, and I appreciated that. Also nice that (for me) figuring out the theme actually aided in solving. Quite enjoyable.

I loved this. The revealer was explicit enough that I could focus on finding the overflowing entries (which I didn’t realize were symmetrically placed until the end).

I liked the added challenge of solving online and not being able to write in the additional letters. It was a good workout for my aging brain. 

My solve was delayed having to figure out where my mistake was. I have virtually no Spanish and a smattering of Italian so BUONO crossing NUOVE seemed right at the time. I really should have known better!

I thought I got it (“the missing letters are all Bs, Us, or Ts!”), until I realized that didn’t work. That bummed me out.

Then I got it, but got confused trying to keep track of missing letters on four different sides. That put me behind.

And in the meantime, I got stumped several times by what (to me) seemed like an abundance of obscure trivia. That felt a bit cheeky.

But in the end, a can-do attitude prevailed and I finished the puzzle. It may not have been my favorite, but I appreciate the effort… and the opportunity for some booty-ful punning.

This was absolutely miserable. Not fun at all. And super sloppy - yes the missing letters were symmetrical but they were basically random on the clues themselves - impossible to start figuring out!!! No. I love a Thursday theme and this was awful.
Have mercy! For me, it was indeed scorchingly difficult. I wish I could say I enjoyed the challenge. Respectfully, I feel pretty jerked around.
I think this would have been fun if it had been displayed with the butt out squares present to be filled. If just doesn’t compute on the app imo.

This was devilishly fun.  I quickly figured out (or so I thought) that this puzzle was full of rebuses.  Not so quick, grasshopper said a little voice in my head when I couldn’t find a workable rebus in any of the spaces that seemed to call for one. Plan B, think outside the box.  Solving online, it was a bit hard for me to keep the letters outside the grid in mind, so I was glad to see them at the end.  Impressive that all the butts were there without using the dreaded A word.

Completed the darn thing, but I can’t get the NYT puzzle app on my iPhone to say it’s complete. I double-checked, twice. I entered the dual letters as rebuses, but it still doesn’t click. Is there a special order to the letters if done as a rebus? Should I just put in the letters, and leave the outside letters invisible?

An unpleasant slog.

It's Thursday, so I'll put up with almost anything. But I also go into it thinking "rébus",  which bit me in the butt today.  So, good clever construction, the trivia wasn't too trivial (my first time salmon fishing was on a boat in San Pablo Bay).  But I really hate having to go back and clear out a letter from umpteen rebuses.  Not sure paper and pen would have helped.  Maybe.
Personally I thought this was stretching it a bit. (A whole lot, in fact).

I really think this one would have needed an asterisk for the theme clues. It would have been much more enjoyable that way, to me at least.

I figured out the theme (more or less) in the NW corner, the AILS was a giveaway, but I struggled to find other clues that demanded the same, especially as  there wasn't really a method to it. It had a layer too much for me.

Also, since when do we discuss theme entires in the "tricky clues" section? If they are fun to discuss, why not just do it in the designated area for theme clues?

I’m perfectly ok with out-of-bounds puzzles, they’re clever, and I enjoy the challenge. However, there was no title in the app that could’ve helped solvers be on the lookout, so at first it was a slog, and then having to remember what letters were outside the grid was a bit tedious.  

A great puzzle, but not an app friendly one.

I got BUTT OUT pretty early on and was expecting some sort of rebus related to the word BUTT that never materialized. Managed to get the fill correctly only because of the crossing clues, and never ended up figuring out this trick until reading the column. Some sort of visual cue to help track where the off-grid letters were to be would have made the discovery of the puzzle theme much more delightful.

I could see there were missing letters but kind of ignored that because of struggling with the names of people and films etc. 

The word 'BUTT isn't intuitive for me - nor BUTT OUT, although of course I've heard of them, and TUSH isn't used at all, so the trick wasn't as cute as for some. Not too shabby though.

I could only think that a waiter pulls out a C-ork. And ELIM? I could only find Bible/Church references.
Great puzzle.
No buts about it, I liked this puzzle and enjoyed solving it.  Thanks, Dan!

This puzzle kicked my... well, you know. 
I didn't enjoy it, but it was a well made puzzle.
Puzzle drove me crazy but once I figured out the trick, I was tickled pink. It was CHEEKY in the best possible way. So, Constructor, you are NTA.

I hated it.  
Now that I'm done and I've read the explanation,
 it's kind of cute.
Fun and tough. Too bad it wasn't a rebus after all. I enjoy the extra complaining on a Thursday.
Not a common Thursday experience for me, but the gimmick clicked right away with tush.  As such was a fun solve, but I have been there with those who trudged.
I LOVED this!  Thank you so much, Dan Caprera!
A bit tough without coffee, but I'm a fan.
Humbs down.

My Neighbor TOTORO is a film by Studio Ghibli, an animation studio more famous in the US for the film Spirited Away, and perhaps Princess Mononoke or Howl's Moving Castle. Totoro was a seminal part of my childhood and remains a beautiful film with poignant themes about family and children facing difficulty. Despite the less-than-saccharine content, it's heartwarming and encouraging, and I'd urge those unfamiliar with it to give it a try. It won't be for everyone (like this puzzle, I expect!) but is a major cultural touchstone for a lot of kids of Asian descent.

Loved it!  It made me think outside the box and had some toughened up cluing, making it appeal to my Thursday fun ethic.  

ANO and URANUS.  Coincidence?  I think not.

I really disliked this one. I can forgive clues for which I'm just not clever enough to figure them out, but that's not what these felt like, if I'm being honest.

This was fun -- *and* I benefited from printing it out and doing it by hand, which is how I learned to solve many of these trickier thematic puzzles. My dad and I used to sit together with the paper when I was a kid, back in the 2000s (we lived in a rural area with no television -- thank goodness), and he taught me how to think flexibly in order to solve NYT puzzles. My mind was always blown -- and still is -- when something like this arose, and I am grateful for the time I had with my dad and the memories a puzzle like this provides (even if there's some hand-wringing in the process before I crack the code).
My friend, Hugh Janus, would love this puzzle.

Dear puzzle constructor,

Please do not listen to these people carping on about their dislike of your puzzle. It was brilliant and creative. Their complaints say way more about them than they say about your work. I look forward to Thursdays because it is the one day where the word 'puzzle' is emphasized a bit more than most days. As someone who has attempted to create crosswords myself, I know what a grind it can be. These kinds of puzzles allow a solver to connect - in a small way - with the creators, because we get a glimpse into the wit that spawned the deviousness of breaking the orthodoxy. Some people want the same meals -oatmeal, a PB&J, and  spaghetti - every day. These are the folks that get uncomfortable with variety and anything that challenges their dogma. 

Don't listen to them. The vast majority of us don't bother to weigh in on online sounding boards. They are the repositories for curmudgeons.

I would like to share a concept that many people in this comment section (and the elected officials we are sadly stuck with in the US) seem to find difficult to grasp. Just because you don’t like something doesn’t mean it is terrible, or shouldn’t exist, or that other people shouldn’t like it. If you don’t like something, don’t partake and move on. You don’t need to rant about it and try to stop others from enjoying it. To everyone griping about the puzzle and complaining that this type of Thursday-style PUZZLE should not exist or not be published in the NYT: thank you for reminding me why I typically stay away from these comments. The upper right proved particularly tricky for me. I was able to solve as I realized which words were arbitrarily truncated.  And yes I saw the final animation indicating the rearward jokes.  Nope, I hadn't had those words composed.

My failing maybe, but(t) I don't think this was a good theme implementation at all.  :(

There was a time—not too long ago, some 6 or 7 years ago when I first started solving—that the challenge this puzzle posed would be par for the course for a Thursday, both the fill and “the trick.” The comment section already existed then. Question for the editors: why does the puzzle allow ñ in one word that is not reflected in the crossing word? I get confused (and then a little frustrated) by “ano” ≠ “año” every time it’s in here, and while I understand you leave out diacritics like accent marks, ñ is treated as a different letter in Spanish than n. It seems like if ñ is included, it should also be an ñ in the crossing direction (not an n). 

I’m not just venting; I would genuinely like to know the reasoning, or maybe hear another example of this that explains how it’s a consistent puzzle style guide and not just an allowance for ñ. (Rather than just cluing  for “ano”, which those who enjoyed this puzzle will be familiar with, if you are going to use that word!)

Loved this one! I giggled my way through the entire solve. From the bonus theme entries of ANO and URANUS to all of the BUTTing OUT words being synonyms, I thought it was a brilliant Thursday construction. It brought up a memory of a road trip from Wisconsin to Arizona that I took with my two youngest kids who were 6 and 10 at the time. We were playing the ABC game to pass the time. We had left St Louis, MO that morning heading to the Meramec Caverns. We were up to the letter U and my son hollered out URANUS. Well, of course I didn’t believe him. He swore he saw that word. Sure enough, just another mile down the road was the giant advertisement for the URANUS Fudge Factory 🤣 We saw at least a dozen signs advertising this legitimate company. We still laugh about it almost ten years later and every once in a while my son will holler URANUS when we get to the letter U.
This was a stretch for me to solve, but great fun. I love that the constructor has fulfilled a lifetime dream.

Advice to the easily frustrated (extremely well represented here already):
SKIP the things that don’t make sense.
FILL IN the things that do make sense.
If you do both of these, eventually you will have enough filled in to allow the light bulb to go on.

It’s beating your head against the trick BEFORE you get the trick that is frustrating you.

With just a couple of crosses, the three names in question fall in easily, n'est-ce pas? (Also, Alain-René Lesage is the author of Gil Blas, thus I’d argue not all that obscure.)

TAUTEN may not be common but, again, eminently deducible: to draw tight is to tighten. Tight and taut are synonyms, and most adjectives can become verbs with an -en ending. Voilà, we have TAUTEN. 

THOU was signaled loudly as slang because its clue was slang. I’ve never written a grant proposal seeking a “nice chunk of dough.”

The clueing for SEEP is tricky in one way: SEEP is not quite a synonym for permeate, but prepositional phrases derived from it are: coffee can either SEEP or permeate into your pillow if you’re not careful in the morning. The latter feels maybe a tad awkwardly phrased, but has been around for almost 500 years. Besides, with 59A calling for a plural, what else could S _ _ _ be?

And I really don’t understand your nit with MOPE. How is being in the dumps not moping?

Our vaunted editors do sometimes get a clue flat out wrong (case in point, ETC yesterday). And obscurity of trivia is very much in the eye of the beholder. Plus, I fully honor anyone’s right to just be plain annoyed with a puzzle, as you were today. 

Maybe I’m just in a puzzle-defending mood.

@Emerald This seems needlessly pedantic. Crosswordese does not follow strict rules of language. If you want the character to be an ñ in both directions, though would generally require two foreign language words to cross each other, which is a no-no in crossword construction (a word or name requiring specialized knowledge should be crossed with more general word or else the puzzle easily becomes unsolvable). 
If this has happened to you "every time it's here", you should be able to figure out what they're looking for. Otherwise you come across as purposefully not getting it just to complain.
